head.supplied: 20/1/69 ¶ ¶ Herewith, dear Dr Story, I return the list of the names of the plants you so very kindly sent You will find them all named according to our ¶ latests ¶ observations. ¶ ¶ The beautiful ...

div.p: DX19 Cotton/Story Papers, University of Tasmania Archives, Hobart.
Herewith, dear Dr Story, I return the list of the names of the plants you so very kindly sent You will find them all named according to our latests observations.

The beautiful supply of Anthocercis Tasmanica and of Helichrysum [lyropodiondes]
H. lycopodioides ?
pleased me very much —
You have again shown new localities for rare plants.
Among the fresh water plants you will find doubtless yet many hitherto overlooked. Even the smallest and most insignificant of them will be welcome
Trusting you will continue your most valuable communications I remain your regardful

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
The little creeping plant named Geranium N. 4 seems to me Veronica [phbya]
V. plebeja ?
However flowers & fruits are wanting!
Leucopogon collinus Br occurs in your collection without number. It is near L. ericoides
I would advise to adopt simply a current number for all your plants. You will find that such numbers will aid us both with the greatest facility

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Brachycome
MS addition by M or Story — check: '2349'.
This number might have been added at anytime since the list was returned 2 Story. It might have been a cataloguing number for whatever herbarium it was deposited within. But I can't find any record in AVH of such aspecimen collected by Story in any of herbaria included in their database

cell.p:
Aster ran[uclosus]
Aster
ramulosus ?
The author is Labillardiere. Can Ab be construed as a non standard abbreviation?
Ab.
there is œ above the second letter of the second word - same hand as other annotations.
Same comment. These are difficult to handle and I suggest that unless it is absolutely clear that the old regions are by a known person the note merely say added in an unknown hand at an unknown time, Or words to that effect.

cell.style: padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;

padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Aster Gunnii
A published name Aster gunnii has not been found (APNI, IPNI, each accessed 12 March 2022).
D.C.

padding-left: 0.0556in; padding-right: 0.0556in; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in; border: none;
cell.p:
Aster argophyllus [Leib]
MS addition by M or Story — check: 'musk'.

cell.p:
Helichrysum [aenis papposinea]
I can make no sense of this; bronze something? the nearest epithet I can get is papillosum , described by Labillardiere.
Lab

cell.p:
31
these are bracketed - how to indicate this?

24
these are bracketed - how to indicate this?
I do not know from this where the bracket starts and finishes in each case, or is it a single very long bracket?

cell.p:
Ozothamnus
MS annotation by Story: 'Geranium No. 4 is Veronica Plebeya Fl. Ofrt. [vinasits]. Leucopgon Collinus'. I don't fully understand where "Geranium No. 4" comes from. It seems as if there is an additional list not present here. Where abouts is the annotation on the letter
